title: 112_hr2559
content: The "Helping Homeless Heroes Act of 2011" enhances comprehensive service programs for homeless veterans. The "Helping Homeless Heroes Act of 2011" amends Section 2011 of title 38, United States Code to enhance grants for new construction, expansion, remodeling, or acquisition of facilities for homeless veterans. The Secretary cannot deny a grant application solely because the entity plans to use funding from other sources, as long as a private nonprofit organization will oversee the project. The Secretary can approve a grant application for a for-profit limited partnership or limited liability company if it meets specific criteria under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 and is financially responsible. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to study and develop improved fiscal controls and payment methods for per diem payments under section 2012(a) of title 38, United States Code within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must study and develop better payment methods for grants under section 2011 of title 38, United States Code, including considering payments from other government departments and private entities. A report on the findings and developed method must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is required to study and improve payment methods for grants under section 2011 of title 38, United States Code. A report on the findings and proposed method must be submitted to Congress within one year. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2007 through 2013 is specified. Modification of grant program for homeless veterans with special needs. Modification of grant program for homeless veterans with special needs. Inclusion of eligible entities for grants and per diem payments, including male homeless veterans with minor dependents. Amendments made to subsections (a) and (b) of section 2061 of the title. Amendments to section 2061 include the provision of services to dependents of homeless veterans with special needs. Grants can now be used to provide services directly to minors under the care of the homeless veteran receiving assistance. SEC. 104. Modification of authority for provision of treatment and rehabilitation to homeless veterans who are not seriously mentally ill. Amends section 2031(a) to include treatment and rehabilitation for homeless veterans. SEC. 105. Plan to end veteran homelessness. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs must submit a plan to Congress within a year to end homelessness among veterans. The plan should analyze existing programs, evaluate coordination between them, and make recommendations for improvement or elimination of ineffective programs. The plan to end homelessness among veterans must include recommendations for new programs, a timeline for implementation, benchmarks for measuring effectiveness, and consideration of veterans in rural areas. SEC. 106 extends authorities for homeless veterans' health care, comprehensive services centers, property transfers, and advisory committee until December 31, 2012, 2014, and 2013 respectively. SEC. 107 reauthorizes appropriations for the Homeless Veterans Reintegration Program. SEC. 108 amends Section 2044(e) of the title to reauthorize $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2012 for financial assistance for supportive services for very low-income veteran families in permanent housing. It also makes a technical amendment to ensure proper subsection references. Section 2061(c)(1) is amended to change the year from 2011 to 2013.
